thread.title: Orleans Parish Clerk of Court announced polling location changes, other pre-Election Day reminders to voters
thread.title_full: Orleans Parish Clerk of Court announced polling location changes, other pre-Election Day reminders to voters

title: Orleans Parish Clerk of Court announced polling location changes, other pre-Election Day reminders to voters
text:
Orleans Parish Clerk of Court announced polling location changes, other pre-Election Day reminders to voters UPDATED 5:53 PM CDT Oct 23, 2015 A Large Text Photos 
Ahead of Saturday's Election Day, Orleans Parish Clerk of Court Arthur Morrell announced polling location changes and other pre-Election Day reminders to voters. Related Police: Parents charged after 4-... 
Aside from the governor and lieutenant governor's races, there are sheriff's races, school board seats up for grabs and several state constitutional amendments on ballots. 
To make sifting through these long ballots easier, you will be allowed to bring a printed out sample ballot, blank or filled out ahead of time, with you into the voting booth. 
You must have a valid id in order to vote. 
There are also some last-minute location changes for folks in Orleans Parish. 
Voters in precincts 15-14C, 17B, 18 and 18A who normally vote at Woodland Presbyterian Church will now vote at Alice B. Harte Elementary School. 
Voters in precincts 6-8 and 6-9 who normally vote at Our Lady of the Rosary will now vote at McDonogh City Park Academy. 
Voters in precincts 5-5 and 5-6 who normally vote at John Dibert School will now vote at Pierre Capdau at Thurgood Marshall. 
Voters in precincts 6-6 who normally St. Peter Claver School will now vote at St. Peter Claver UJIMA Fern Brady Building. 
Voters in precincts 13-9, 10, 12, 13, 14 who normally vote at Isidore Newman School will now vote at Isidore Newman School the Henson Building. 
Voters in precincts 16-5 and 16-6 who normally vote at Kipp Believe College Prep will now vote at Central St. Matthew United Church of Christ. 
Clerk of court Arthur Morell says nearly 13,000 Orleans Parish voters cast their ballots early. That's a few thousand fewer early voters than during the last gubernatorial race. For Election Day, Morrell and his office are expecting 30-32 percent turnout -- which could make for long lines. So Morell says all voters need to be prepared when casting their votes. 
“You can take as much time as you want in the polling booth, but you only have three minutes. We're not going to rush you, but we'd like you to move because we expect to have a little crowd. Sometimes you can have lines, but be a little patient. We'll move you pretty quickly,” said Morrell. 
Polls open on Saturday at 7 a.m. and close at 8 p.m., but the Secretary of State's office says if you're in line at 8 p.m. 
Click here for more details on where you can find a sample ballot specific to your precinct, candidate information and more to prepare you for Election Day.
